clinical_study.brief_title: STAND UP to SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19): Using Behavioural Economics to Reduce Sedentary Behaviour in At-home Office Workers
clinical_study.official_title: STAND UP to SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19): Using Behavioural Economics to Reduce Sedentary Behaviour in At-home Office Workers, a Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: In COVID-19 times, there has been a large increase in number of people working from home; with limited places to go, an abrupt change to people's lives and lack of knowledge about the dangers of sedentary behaviour (SB), it is important to help workers develop and effortlessly incorporate healthy movement routines to optimize daily productivity and health. The combined lack of knowledge on literature on SB profiles of full time, home-based workers, effects of framing of SB reduction strategies, and strategy preference uncertainty makes for a novel study. This will be a 4-week intervention with 3 experimental groups that looks at whether telling a full time, home-based office worker to do pre-selected strategies to break up their sedentary behaviour (SB) (i.e. sitting) will change their SB profiles compared to either letting them select their own strategies (from either a short or long list menu). Investigators are looking to see whether having the choice (or not) to choose strategies in an unfamiliar health related selection (preference uncertainty) will create greater changes in SBs. As well, the researchers are incorporating behavioural economics' choice overload concept with length of choice menus in relation to behaviour change and program engagement. Workers' work-related SB will be measured by a device at baseline and on the last week of the intervention. Workers will be provided with an SB educational video to increase knowledge and motivation for change. Any SB changes in relation to productivity, mental wellness, behaviour intentions etc. will also be measured.

detailed_description.textblock:
Regardless of group assignment, participants will receive the same three-minute educational video at the beginning (week 1) and halfway through (week 3) the intervention. Each group will also receive weekly sedentary behaviour reduction strategies (number varied by group allocation) under the themes of "sit less, stand up, and move often". Participants will be asked to "pre-commit" to 3 strategies (that are either pre-selected for participants ('forced choice') or selected by participants from a short or long list of options at the beginning of each week),and will be reminded of their selection on the Wednesday of each week and will be instructed to self-report their sedentary behaviours at the end of each week (Friday).
An "interested" participant will email research personal with their initial "interest" in which the research personnel will respond by asking them for their phone number with the letter of information (LOI)/informed consent document attached. From there, a phone call will be arranged to go over the document before proceeding with the study. After thoroughly going through the LOI and answering any questions or concerns they may have, participants will be asked for verbal consent and will be instructed to sign (digitally) the LOI/informed consent and send it back to the researcher (via email). Upon received consent, participants will be asked for their home address (for ActivPAL4 delivery) and will be told that they will receive an email with their unique participant ID and link to the first questionnaire (demographic information and secondary outcomes). When the participant receives the link to the first questionnaire, the LOI will be the first page for them to review once again.
Upon completion of the baseline questionnaire, the activPAL4 will be sent by courier (i.e. FedEx) and participants will receive another email with detailed instructions of how to apply the device [i.e. applied to the mid-thigh using Tegaderm (3M)] along with how to contact investigators upon any issues with application. Participants will be instructed to apply the device on Sunday evening (if possible) and to wear the device all day for a period of 5 working days (Monday to Friday). Once participants complete the device measured baseline assessment, they will place the device back in the package it came in, and using pre-paid postage, the device will be picked up (via courier) and they will then be randomized into one of the three experimental conditions preceding the intervention period.
Intervention Week 1. On day one of the intervention (Monday), participants will receive an email containing, 1) a link to watch a 3-minute whiteboard-styled educational video about sedentary behaviour (i.e. health consequences, benefits of breaking up or reducing sedentary behaviour, sedentary behaviour in relation to productivity and mood etc.) and 2) another link that will lead them to a short questionnaire re-assessing knowledge and intentions of sedentary behaviour that were assessed in the first questionnaire they did at baseline (using Sosci and unique ID code); they will be instructed to fill out this questionnaire AFTER watching the video and will serve as a fidelity check. A second email will contain their strategies and pre-commitment options; depending on the condition assignment (as described earlier) participants will either be presented with a sedentary behaviour strategy menu to choose one out of X number of strategies (per three categories) (i.e. short-list or long-list condition) or, be instructed in what they will be doing that week (no-choice condition). After the strategy selection or instruction, participants will be prompted within the same email to pre-commit to three strategies for that week. Wednesday morning, participants will receive an email reminding them of their strategies. In the afternoon, on the last day of the same workweek (Friday), participants will be prompted (via email) with a link (Soci) to self-report their sitting habits (i.e. break frequency and break duration) along with accountability to their commitments.
Intervention Week 2. On the Monday of week 2, strategies will reset as earlier described for each condition. For this week, participants will again be prompted within the same email to pre-commit to three strategies for that week and will again receive an email Wednesday morning reminding them of their chosen strategies. Additionally, they will again be asked to self-report their sitting habits (via link sent through email) (i.e. break frequency and break duration) along with accountability to their commitments on the last day of the week (Friday).
Intervention Week 3. On the Monday of Week 3, strategies will reset as earlier described for each condition. However, for this week, the participants will be reminded of the video they watched at the beginning of the intervention and be asked to re-watch the same video. In line with the same protocol described in the earlier weeks, pre-commitment, self-reported sitting habits and accountability will be measured; along with the reminder email on Wednesday morning.
Intervention Week 4. Week four of the intervention will be the final week. Again, strategies will reset for all conditions. Participants again, will wear the activPAL4's (delivered via FedEx) for a total of five days (Monday to Friday). This will serve as the follow-up objectively (device) measured sedentary behaviour measurement. The participants will receive the same pre-commitment and reminder email as previous weeks. This last week, however, the Friday questionnaire will include all secondary outcomes that were initially assessed at baseline along with a short exit survey asking about participant satisfaction with the intervention.
Follow Up. Follow-up will occur two weeks post-intervention. Participants will recomplete all secondary outcomes that were initially assessed at baseline (with exception to the activPAL measurements).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Upon completion of baseline assessments, all participants will be randomized using an online research randomization program (randomizer.org) with a 1:1:1 allocation ratio, into one of the three experimental conditions (choice menu long list, choice menu short list or no choice).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in work-related quality of life
secondary_outcome.description: Short form 36 health survey (SF-36) measured on a 5-point Likert scale from 1 "all of the time" to 5 "None of the time".

Questions regarding work productivity, concentration and focus will be measured with questions adapted from The Health and Work Questionnaire (HWQ). The HWQ is a multidimensional tool used to measure various aspects of productivity. The HWQ consists of 24 questions, several items being multi-part questions with internal consistency scores ranging from alpha = 0.72 to 0.96. The questions are designed to assess work quality, quantity, and efficiency, as well as impatience, concentration/focus, work satisfaction and non-work satisfaction. For the current study, 15 items were chosen from this questionnaire that were relevant to "home-based" office workers. Items will be assessed with a ten-point response scale, tailored to each question (e.g., "my worst ever" to "my best ever").

Responses will be rated using a 7-point Likert scale scored from 1 (completely disagree) to 7 (totally agree). The question stem is as follows, "For you, sitting for work (e.g. using the computer, doing office work, reading, talking on the phone, sitting in meetings, eating) is.... (i.e. pleasant). An attitude score will be computed by summing the five items and dividing by five.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in percentage of time spent sitting
secondary_outcome.description: The validated three-item modified Occupational Sitting and Physical activity questionnaire (OSPAQ). The OSPAQ is a brief instrument reported to have excellent test-retest reliability (intraclass correlation coefficients = 0.73-0.90), moderate criterion validity for time spent sitting and standing (r = 0.65 and 0.49, respectively), and lower validity for time spent walking (r = 0.29). At each assessment period (baseline, week 1, week 2, week 3, week 4 and follow-up), participants will be asked to record both the number of days they were at work and total number of hours they worked in the last 7 days. Participants will then be asked to record a percentage of time spent sitting, standing, and moving (i.e. walking) (cumulative total of 100%) during work hours on a typical workday in the last 7 days.

Two items will be used to measure perceived behavioural control (e.g., "If I wanted to I could spend more or less time [sitting for ...] per [workday]") and were rated on a 7- point scale from 1 (definitely false) to 7 (definitely true).

One question will be used to measure self-efficacy for 10 different lengths of time (e.g., "How confident are you that you can reduce your [work-related sitting] by [15 minutes or less"]). Items started with "15 minutes or less" and went up to "8 or more hours" and were rated on an 11-point percentage point scale from 0% (not confident at all) to 11 (100% confident).

arm_group.description: On the Monday of each week, participants will be sent a menu of strategies within three categories 1) how to stand up, 2) how to sit less, and 3) how to move more. Each category will have 12 strategies (total 36 strategies); and participants will be asked to pre-commit to one strategy per category. Each week, their strategy selections will reset, and they will have the opportunity to select their three strategies for the upcoming week again. There are no restrictions on choice of re-choosing strategies.

On the Monday of each week, participants will be sent a menu of strategies within the three categories 1) how to stand up, 2) how to sit less, and 3) how to move more. Each category will have 4 strategies (total 12 strategies); and participants will be asked to pre-commit to one strategy per category as above. Each week, their strategy selections will reset, and they will have the opportunity to select their three strategies for the upcoming week again. There are no restrictions on choice of re-choosing strategies.

On the Monday of each week, participants will be notified of three new strategies they should use for the upcoming work week; essentially, being told what to do. The message containing the upcoming week's strategies will state, "Here are three successful previously used strategies that are peer suggested and expert recommended to reduce and break up your sitting that we want you do to this week: A, B, and C." Strategies will be selected from peer-reviewed articles, and each of the three strategies will have one of three themes: stand up, sit less, and move more. These strategies will change each week (to account for the Choice condition's weekly strategy change up). Participants will be asked to 'pre-commit' to the strategy by e-signing a so-called sitting 'oath' and will be reminded of their 'oath' with a mid-week email reminder. All participants will experience all of the 12 strategies, but will be randomly assigned the combinations, to counterbalance any order or combined effects.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or older
- Self-declare working 5 days per week (Monday to Friday)
- Full-time worker/employee (i.e. employed ≥ 30 hours/week)
- Desk-based office worker currently only working from home
- Have access to a computer with Internet and email
- Able to read and write in English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Self-declared medical condition or physical limitation that prevents them from being physically active
- Planning on leaving the current employer or taking a leave of absence for more than 3 consecutive workdays for the duration of the study
